Early Access Review
								Three-on-three ice hockey with a roster of robot players who are like MOBA heroes: Each with different strengths, weaknesses, and special moves. Like a MOBA, you acquire new heroes (called "runners" in this game) with real money, or in-game currency you have to farm. Everyone starts with two runners: A forward (the player that tries to score goals) and a keeper (the player that tries to prevent the other team from scoring goals).Matches are only three minutes long and the matchmaker puts you in with bots if it can't find other players (which is often). Figuring out how to pass and remembering to keep your opponents covered is actually harder than figuring out the controls. After the unavoidable first impression that the game would be easier with a dual-analog controller, you'll quickly become an ace with the mouse-and-keyboard setup.Beautiful graphics, cool heroes, catchy music, easy to learn. All it really needs is a bigger player base.

Early Access Review
								This game has been by far the best free to play game that I have played on steam and it is currently one of the few that I am actually continuing to play because of the community and the continual support of the developers.  This is a long review with a general pros and cons list at the bottom, if you wanna hear me ramble feel free to read but check out the botttom if youre scrolling through and want a quick synopsis.About myself: College athlete with a huge interest in sports and gaming is one of my favorite hobbies.  I enjoy MOBAs such as LOL, DOTA2, and Smite and play them frequently while also enjoying shooters and strategy games.  Honestly sports games havent held much time with me simply because they are $60 new each year and the community disappears immediately for the new version and while fun it gets expensive.  I downloaded this as my weekly free to play game (Cause I want to try new games and see what catches my eye) and got stuck playing all night.  I wanted to beat the bots and after a while I did, I ran into some humans too on occasion and that was even better.  I got my brother and a friend to get the game and now we are competing in the first esports season for this game on Team Shadow Fox (hence the [SFX] tag)  If you see this review, feel free to add me as a friend and I will have no trouble playing with you if you need a teammate or just have a question about the game.About the Game:  Currently it is 3v3 airhockey/icehockey fused with the idea of a MOBA.  You are able to select from a small pool of champions/characters/runners which are given a  couple of abilities to work as a team and outscore your opponents.  Game time is a short 5 minutes so you arent deeply committed to anything and the que times are only 1min long maximum.  There is no pay to win element of this game as the "real money" currency is meant for asthetic skins or hats or unlocking a runner early.  There is a regular in game currency used for picking from "implants" that can help customize your champion from improving his speed, defense, offense, or supporting your teammates.  The in game currency with enough grinding will also certainly unlock champions you are hoping to play.  There is also a free champion rotation to help players try them out and buff their champion pool.Roles Currently are simple and the champion pool currently has 8 runners in it with more on the way.  Strikers are designed to be fast and add power to their shots.  Supports are designed for passing options as well as to buff their team or debuff their opponents such as speed ups, slocks, dislodging the puck.  And of course the goalie who has abilities to help keep the puck out of your own net.  Hopefully as new champions come out the strategies and playstyles will be as complex and diverse as one could hope for.The Community: By far the reason I enjoy this game so much right now.  First off, how frequently are you going to be able to speak to the game developers of some of the bigger companies like Riot or Blizzard and actually get a solid response?  The developers will talk to you, get your opinions, tell you about upcoming game builds or runners, even friend you on steam.  One even helped troubleshoot a graphical error I was encountering in one of the early patches this year.  They are hard working and are continually working to improve the game and its player base all while having fun too.  I know the game is still young, but I know these guys wont abandon it and leave it in the purgatory that is early acess alpha games.They hold very frequent events and tournaments which is great for meeting other players, testing your skill and watching some of the best teams go head to head.  It adds the fun competitive edge without going over the top.  There are weekly mini tournaments with which to compete in that are low stress and fun while on the weekends there are solo player and team based tournaments which are designed for the serious competitors and the best players will compete in these.  Oddly enough this is how I got roped into the game when I followed the twitch stream and some of the best players in the game (Hypnos and Pit) brought in a guy with less than 10hrs play time into what felt like a pro event.  It was a lot of fun and nobody was too upset or frustrated with how lousy I was and we still came out ok.  On top of that Spearhead games has a dedicated sports caster Jethro Tull who will make you feel like your actually at the arena.  Finally all of the players who frequent the game all seem to be chill individuals who have no trouble helping out a new player, like new ideas, and are generally fun to play against.  They will tell you gg and actually mean it.My final Pros vs Cons listPros-Free to play and not pay to win-3v3 team competitive experience-Short time comittment ~5min-Well designed and balanced characters (Devs will make balance changes)-Solid repeat player base-Competitive tournaments and ranking system-Decent soundtrack (repetitive after a few games though)-Player base is friendly in game-Devs listen and care both in forum and in streamed events and personal message even-Devs will create runners based on fan suggestions (Obviously it needs to be feasible and balanced but it has happened)-Community appears to be growing if only slowly-Great game for groups of friends (Ideally 3 or 6)Cons/What needs to improve-Small player base (outside of events its tough finding a full match if you are solo, although this is improving)-It's alpha so still a glitch here and there, mostly graphical, nothing debilitating-Small Champion Pool (New game so its to be expected and it should grow)-Ranking system is not necessarily tied with matchmaking system (New patch just came out, but currently there is nothing thats going to stop you from being matched with the weekend warrior if you are new)-Ranking System is ELO which means its a solo player rating for a team based game (Currently this is the only feasible option, there arent enough players for a tiered system like LOL or Smite and this system will minimize the damage if you do get matched with a pro on your first day out)-AI is nothing special, they look for straight line passes and shots even if it across the middle of your own goal with the other team in the way.  If you have a full group there is no issue, but if not dont expect the bots to be carrying your butt to victory.Finally any issues you do have with the game, the devs want to hear about them.  Post in the forums, pitch ideas, visit the streams during tournaments.  They will answer you, other players will answer you.  Graphical glitch, they can help.  Need friends to play with, I added 4 friends this week cause I posted I wanted to develop my sunday teams roster.  The best thing you can do for yourself and this game is to download it, get two friends to download it, play together and compete.  You wont be disappointed and if you are say so and check it out the next patch.

Early Access Review
								This game is really great. I don't know any other way to put it. You know you are having a great time when your heart is racing during the game, and afterwards you still can't stop shaking. For anyone downloading the game for the first time, let me start by saying that as of right now, going in at a random time and clicking play to find 5 other people is very rare. It may be discouraging and feel like a dead game, but it is very much the opposite. Instead of deleting the game or never playing it because you can't find full games, watch the streams, go to the forums, and get help from a community member. Tournaments are almost daily, and pick-up games are very often. Finding a team is usually not too hard, and you can make it easy by inviting some friends to come play.Essentially, the gameplay is just 3 on 3 hockey like matches, set in the future. There are a number of different runners designed to fill certain roles on a team, each with different speeds and abilities. Even though there is currently not a massive amount of runners, I am yet to get bored of the intense and exciting matches. There is no story/campaign mode, and the entire thing is a multiplayer game. If a player ques and finds no people or only a few (as happens often) then bots will fill in for the missing slots. Most players like to focus on a single runner to excel at, but once in the character selection nothing is holding you back from choosing any of the characters you have unlocked (all characters can be unlocked with in game currency, or real money, but please, do not get the impression that this is a pay to win game. Certain runners are stronger than others but every single one can be played well, and no runner is too far unbalanced.) The matches are a short 5 minutes long in an arena with each team trying to shoot the puck into the other teams goal.The community for this game is awesome. Its very friendly, and alot of the members have almost the entire community on their friends list at this point. The community isn't very large at all, and alot of the players in it have been playing since the start, but you get to know everybody this way, making it really great despite the sizeHonestly, this game has so many flaws currently, despite so many already being fixed. Lack of players, bad bot AI, bugs, balancing issues, and various other things all pull this game back. But i think it says something that even amidst all these problems that on other games would be enough to make me quit, this game has kept me coming back for more.Seriously, check out this game, and remember, don't feel discouraged when at first you can't find anyone.

								It's like a chopped-down NHL game with comic-book cyber-fi competitors.  And it's awesome.The game's simply a blast.  Rather, it's fun in its own simplicity.  You control one of three team mates (decently effective bots or players take the other slots), and a disc-puck-thing is dropped between you and the opposing team (where it is placed, precisely, is determined by last goal scored).  The teams rush for it, and use their unique players' abilities to snatch, slow, and stop the puck-handler.  Goals can be made by either dunking/running for a touchdown (run the puck into the net), or by shooting it in.  The grab-release mechanic allows for quick execution of shots, and easy interceptions.This is still a very young game, so as long as the core components aren't messed with and there is some major (and I mean major, as far as the magically-laggy home screen is concerned) MAJOR performance issues addressed.  Personally I feel this game should run just fine for everyone, but for some reason it hates my (more than adequate) graphics card, and pretty much any time I'm not actually in a game (where there are zero server side or client side latency issues), the graphics seem to progressively drop the framerate.  It almost feels like their fog effects don't ever fully dissipate and just stack invisible particles, or something.tl;dr Try it!  It's free, and it's fun!

								*Quick note - I see a lot of reviews on here with like 0.3 hours played or less. My teammate clocked in 146 hours and I'm over 50 so perhaps ignore the positive reviews that show the person installed it and ran the title screen over people like me that actually put some time in. Sadly the fact this game is even still listed on Steam reenforces the feeling that over the last 2 years Steam has gone from a solid platform for good games into an unchecked and uncontrolled shovelware factory for novice made indie garbage.Funny a friend introduced me to this game maybe two years back because he was friends with one of the devs. Comically over time said unnamed dev grew tired of some of the BS going on with the leads decision making which becomes a large part of this review.When I first played the game it was actually fun. Each release the game got worse and worse with a clear focus on skins, visuals and other garbage they planned to monetize rather than making the game work. Believe it or not the net code got worse as it became clear the team really had no idea what they were doing when it came to networking. So rather than fix the match making and network issues they changed the menus, added new sounds and other pointless crap that didn't matter because you rarely could join a game and when you did you'd probably get disconnected at some point anyhow.There were so many problems and I wrote about them on my teams website and various other places for the devs to review but jump ahead it looks like they gave up much like the majority of the player base who they alienated during feed back sessions and the tournaments they put on.All in all it's quite sad to have seen the potential and then to watch them flush it. July 25, 2015I guess I'm not the only one to have forgotten about this game. ACE really hasn't changed much since last year. The menus changed (for worse), there are some new characters and storyline stuff, and the tutorial is even less helpful, but the core game is unchanged. Network problems are undetectable, mostly because you will be placed in all bot matches within 60 seconds, and there is no one playing anymore. There's a bunch of skins and tournament stuff, but the game is pretty lifeless now.Yes, the game is free, give it a shot if you are interested. Maybe you'll be one of the people that jumps in and gets hooked. I really don't expect most people to be like that. I found more players months ago, and I think server region splits really hurt. Even if you can find players, I don't feel the gameplay is satisfying enough. The arena feels huge and everything feels sluggish for a 5 minute match. Abilities will only be used a few times in a match, and it just doesn't feel fun. Those abilities are also still hard to land or identify, with particle overload making the game hard to understand as a viewer.The developers work on growing a community, but I don't feel Early Access is being used to make the game more appealing. The old list of stretch goals has disappeared, and little issues remain. Updates have mostly been fixes and Ranked stuff, it seems like gameplay is not going to change. The tutorial uses a lot more words to teach less (it doesn't even teach passing now), and the menus are still unintuitive. Currency and progression systems are not explained clearly, and I still feel the power progression system is a mistake for a competitive game. There are only 2 supported resolution options listed, and graphics options are barren. Oh but they give away game currency and items, so usability issues disappear because free stuff. The Trello board is empty, the forums are full of "we appreciate the feedback, updates are coming", and the match lobby still doesn't have team-only chat. The game won't be marketed until it is finished, and I expect there will be another overhaul to the menu and graphics, but the core issues won't change. It's not an engaging game for most players. With goalies, the game is a sluggish 2v2 centered around blocking everything. The VERY early alpha feeling still shows up, with even the tutorial throwing up error codes. It was interesting to see the process of development, but I can't see myself putting even dozens of hours into this game, or recommending it to friends. Almost a year ago I felt the game wasn't ready, and hoped it would be stronger in 6 months. Dozens of small tournaments later, the game is still rightfully Early Access.

Early Access Review
								Summary:This soccer-style game is obviously still in the early stages. The gameplay is fun, hold left mouse button down to hold the disk, and release to shoot. The cut-scene and runner artwork is very well done, the "runners" look cool and the heavily outlined style (similar to Borderlands) gives the game a cool comic book feel. The biggest downfall of this game has to be the home screen UI. It is bloated, outdated, and makes you feel like you're playing a pay-to-play game on facebook. All-in-all, the gameplay of Arena: Cyber Evolution is genuinely fun, though they need to focus on sharpening their UI, Increasing their player base, and balancing the runners. I'm going to give it a 2 stars (out of 5) with definite potential. Pros:-Gameplay is very fun. Moving with WASD and shooting the disk with the mouse feels good and fluid.-Intro stage is well done. The "Entry Test" is a good way to immerse the player while also teaching them to play. -Lines come off of your character to show where your allies and current aim are, giving the game a very cool geometric feel. -A lot of the artwork is really good, though the UI work is absolutely abhorrent. -The leveling system is clear and easy to understandCons:-Players move very slow. A small speed bost would help the flow of the game.-General character balance. There is a goalie ability that can pull the disk to them (even if the disk is already inside the goal) way too frequently. I suggest replacing this with a dive move or increasing the cooldown time to somewhere around a minute.-Bloated home screen UI. This is the first impression of the game and what people have to stare at while waiting for matches. Put some effort in to it. Things that need to happen before this game is good:-Update the awful UI. It looks bloated like a facebook game. -ENFORCE THE GOAL LINE. If the disk goes past the goal line it should be a point.-Show a quick replay of the goal after it is made.

Up there with the likes of 'Why are we here', 'Is there a god' and 'Why do kids love Cinnamon Toast Crunch?'. Up until this day, this question has never been answered. Which is why I'm here.A good game invokes emotion. A good game tells a story. A good game, is a good game. ACE checks all but one of these boxes. ACE gets you to jump out of your seat, fist pumping in the air as you score that game-winning post goal. ACE gets you, head in hands, groaning at the incompotency of your goalie. ACE gets you to do all of this, and more. But what ACE doesn't do, is tell a story. What ACE does, is give the player, the oppurtunity to craft their OWN story. Their OWN legend. A game rich with replayability, a game rich with no glass ceiling, a game rich with a budding, growing e-sports scene. ACE let's you tell your own tale, your tale of bounce shots, your tale of overtime stress-fests, your tale of that one time where you scored a goal by bouncing the puck off their goalie. No other game does this, because no other game can. ACE acheives what very many dream of, but even more will never ever achieve.Outside of the game, you find the company. The team behind, and pardon the rhyme, the dream. Spearhead Games. Responsible for such successes as Tiny Brains, as Stories. As ACE. With a community manager that cares, and a team of streamers dedicated to bringing you the best content they can at hitbox.tv/spearheadgames or twitch.tv/spearheadgames ACE is constantly changing. ACE isn't just a game. Spearhead Games isn't just a company. These two things, brought together, are a fire. A fire that we, the players. We, the viewers. We, the dreamers, stoke. Fuelling that desire to reach for the stars then bring them back. Flames licking at heros. Smoke billowing into the endless sky, the endless possibilites. I can only tell you so much about ACE. I can only put into words, how great this game is, if you just give it a chance. It's up to you to decide if you like the game. 								A wise man once said "to make a great video game you have to capture a moment in time, whether it's 5 minutes, or an hour. After you have that moment you have to expand upon it until it's something that people not only love, but will cherish for years". I know that it's entirely pre-emptive to say that A:CE will be around for years to come; but I hope it does, I really do. The controls are smooth, the matches are fast-paced and involving, and the art is amazing. The developers have done an excellent job of making everyone on the team feel important also. Slower PC ? Don't have the fine-tuned twitch reflexes of someone who's been playing NHL games for a decade ? Doesn't matter. You can be a lumbering goalie and STILL play an exceedingly rewarding (and more importantly; necessary) role for your team. A:CE strays from other MOBA games in that "tanking" or "support" is FUN! You might not be as fast as a forward, but there's nothing like freezing the enemy team solid on your side of the court, passing a rink-long pass, and watching your forward breeze by the goalie. It's teamwork personified; and it's FUN.Give this game a try guys. I never-ever write reviews, but I just had brag on this diamond-in-a-very-rough stone that are other MOBA-type games.

								The controls were just far to bizarre for me, my underwhelming ultra-special move didn't even work for a full bout (I pressed Space a lot and not once did it trigger), and I can never tell when my AI team mate is going to pass to me (I haven't tried live players yet- I don't feel like the controls are natural enough to even consider it). Plus, I can never seem to catch the puck. Banging the left mouse button to steal and then having to _hold_ that same button to keep the puck (and then _release_ the button to shoot) is immensely counter-intuitive. The whole time I felt like I was fighitng the controls. The WASD thing just seems like a terrible design choice- something more akin to a space simulator movement system seems like a better fit- where you have a "thrust" button, with directionality based on the mouse facing. I can see what they are trying to do, akin to an old double-joystick shooter, but it just doesn't feel "right". I would much rather see it "catch" the puck without much input, and reserve holding down the button to "power up", then release to shoot if they are going to do it that way (something like the old NHL hockey games from my youth). At least then you'd have a little variability on how you were shooting, rather than every shot going at the same speed (unless you manage to hit it with your special move, that is). "Events" are massively annoying with how counter-intuitive the controls already are- they need to be something that can be turned off, especially when first learning the game. And the game seems to memory leak something fierce- after two or three bouts everything lags and I have to shut it down and reload. The graphics settings don't seem to work right- the game looked fine until I went to look at the resolution options, and then, not changing resolution at all, it suddenly went all stretched out like the aspect ratio is wrong. I didn't select anything, I just opened up the drop-down and left it right where it was. And full screen versus windowed mode should stick between sessions. Also, it seems that some of the time when you check "full screen" it actually remains in windowed mode and vice-versa. All in all a really rocky start for what sounds like a fairly interesting concept. But I can't stomach the controls or the other issues after playing for nearly an hour. Uninstalled. Not recommended.

								Okay I know what you're thinking "this guy has only played 0.1 hours of the game so he has no idea what he's talking about". Just here me out. This game has issues from the get go. After my first of the game, I had no desire to play further. For starters, the AI is the worst I have ever seen. My goalie started with the puck, turned around and shot it in our own goal. 4 times. same thing from the other team. Their goalie either just handed it to my team or just turned around and shot it in his own goal. On top of that, i had no issues with framerate, but it is slow. The movement speed is simply slow and not engaging. A game about space hockey should be fun, energetic and exciting! However it just doesnt feel that way. In a game centered on sport action, the last thing you want is boredom as the player is running across the field to score a goal. I understand that this is early access, but if you're going to release a game to the public you need to make sure that it works. The bugs in this game can range from annoying to "are you ♥♥♥♥ing serious?". I'm sure these will all be fixed in the future but when you want to get some fans early on, the last thing you want is to drive them away with a game that infuriates them. As many others say, it's a good premise. However as it stands, it's a boring game that needs improvement. I would reccomend for starters, to make the game faster paced. This way new players can look past some of the bugs and feel the rush of scoring a goal or intercepting a pass. Fast paced action in a game like this is key. Next, fix the bugs. I'm sure that they will, but making a game public access with bugs like this is not smart if you want people to buy your "adopter" packs and such. Nobody wants to put money into a game that has bugs like these. I want this game to succeed I really do, I wouldn't have written this otherwise (I'm sure my gramatical errors show that I'm in a rush to type this). But it needs improvement. Early Acces is becoming more and more of a grey area as more and more games accept the practice, and if you want to compete, you cannot make a game like this public. It needs time is all, just give it some time.

Besides the superpowers the game is basically a football game (I'm from Europe, so I guess it's soccer for the Americans reading this.). The game would've been rated higher if it weren't for the fact that it's basically dead. 								I went into this one with no expectations and having no idea what the point of the game was at all. I think that made the experience better. That being said, it’s an early access game with definite room for improvement, but it gets a few things right. Let’s begin.TLDR: Not RecommendedThe GoodACE – Arena: Cyber Evolution is like futuristic air hockey, only it’s played at a life-size scale. You can select from a few characters to play as (others you have to unlock through in-game currency). Each character has special abilities he or she can use to aid you and your team on the path to victory. I’m sure most of us (if not all of us) have played air hockey before. It’s fun and it’s a fairly acceptable way to kill some time. As the game stands now in it’s current state, that’s the highest praise I’ll be giving it. A dressed up game of air hockey.The BadAs I mentioned above, some characters need to be unlocked through in-game currency. The same holds for character customization options (skins and the like). Most of it you’d be forking over actual currency to get and that, to me, is an utter waste for a game like this.The game has only two resolution settings, neither of which fit my monitor. Sad day.The only other real complaint I had had to do with the controls. Well, one specific control. Holding down the left mouse button allows you to grab and hold onto the disc (puck). Releasing the left mouse button (in theory) allows you to shoot the disc in the direction your cursor is facing. 70% of the time when I tried to shoot the disc, it floated in front of me in a pathetic manner and this often resulted in the enemy team taking control of it.The MehInitially, I thought the artwork for the game looked like it was going to be my kind of thing. It has a sort of Borderlands-esque feel to it, right? Not so much. Actual in game graphics didn’t really do it for me. They just seemed lacking.This game is very much an online game. However, I played for a good long while and only ever had matches with bots. the community is, for all intents and purposes, much like a cemetery. You don’t need other players to play, luckily. As I said, you can play with bots.Verdict: NayWhile part of me feels this is a bit harsh for a free-to-play game, I just can’t bring myself to recommend it as it is now. Maybe once it hits it’s final release I will revisit it and give it another go. Until then, I think I’ll stick to real air hockey and I would advise all of you to do the same. As always, thanks for reading.

Early Access Review
								Depending on how long you've been gaming, you will either see this game as yet another future team sports game, or the first of its kind.  The genre had been done to death by the late 80's/early 90's, but this game has online multiplayer which sounded like fun.Unfortunately, there is rarely anyone online. The most it's ever shown is one person online as it spent 3 minutes trying to connect a game unsucessfully. For all I know, that one person was just me. In short, MP is pretty much a no-go depending on which time zone you are in. I'm yet to find anyone else to play with.This leaves you to play against the bots, which would be fine if you had any control over your own team. Unfortunately, you only control one player or  at least try to with the slow and clunky controls, but that doesn't matter as your team rarely pass to you anyway. You are left running around on your own as one hogs the disk while your goalie usually ends up as the highest scorer... for the other team.  Lots of own goals.  First rule of team sports games -  The player controls whoever has the "ball" or at least has the ability to pass to and from bots. Otherwise its just BORING.Without the inability to switch players on your team or even find anyone online, it's just not fun at all and there's really nothing new here. I wanted to like this game, and as it's still in early development, there's lots of room for improvement. As it is though, it's still pretty buggy, low on content, lacks any depth and has microtransactions for useless gear. I can't recommend this to anyone.

								I am going to assume by the time you read this you have checked out some trailers of the game and you pretty much know what this game is about. In a nutshell the game is an intergalatic air hockey simulator in which you pick a Runner and try to score goals. You play against another team of up to 3 players. Matches last 5 minutes and if undecided run into sudden death, where a golden goal principe is enforced. I like the competive element of the game, it feels like a real sport.First the bad: I tried the game a few months back and it was still very much an early access product. It lacked proper dedicated servers and the interface was cluncky at best. It also had quite a few serious bugs, like loading screens timing out or games starting and not being balanced properly (3v2 or 1v4). At the time I quit, but hey, the game was in early access and it didn't claim to be anything else. Now the good: About two weeks back I logged back in and was pleasantly suprised: dedicated servers, loading bugs completely fixed and a new slick interface (that naturally could still use some work here and there). It has come to a point where I would definitely recommend the game. There are still some issues, for example some problems with quests registering multiple times, but the core game itself is solid, fun and very easy to get into. The worst problem at the moment though is the limited number of players. Personally I don't mind playing some bots every now and again, but when this happens a lot the game loses some of its tension, because it is great to face off against other players. Besides, the game is free, so why not give it a bash. My final thoughts? With some more players this game would be great fun. It feels amazing to score that deciding goal a few seconds before the timer runs out, let alone win a match that has run into sudden death by a well timed shot or a great long pass. Do yourself a favor and check out Arena: Cyber Evolution, or ACE for short.
